poem:
**Banned Pages**

The hum of whispers  
seals words away—  
inked defiance bound  
in paper jails.  
Yet in quiet corners,  
illuminated by  
curious eyes,  
the forbidden breathes—  
a symphony of silenced  
voices daring  
to utter truths,  
alive in the space  
between censorship  
and the unquenchable fire  
of human curiosity.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Banned! The 20 books they didn’t want you to read The banning of books, it would be easy to think, is a relic of less enlightened ages. The Catholic church, in a last spasm of rectitude, added Jean-Paul Sartre, Alberto Moravia and Simone de Beauvoir to its Index of Forbidden Books during the 1940s and 50s, but then abandoned the list, which had lasted four centuries, in 1966. Public book burnings by Nazis or McCarthyites, too,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
